thought.author: Larry Tesler
description: How would modern user interfaces look like without copy & paste? Today's issue of #ThoughtsOnProgramming features Larry Tesler, who invented the cut, copy and paste commands during his time at Xerox PARC.
thought.quote: You cannot reduce the complexity of a given task beyond a certain point. Once you've reached that point, you can only shift the burden around.

thought.author: Martin Fowler
description: In a professional environment, the ratio of time spent reading versus writing code is about 10 to 1. Producing clean, comprehensive and maintainable code is of utmost importance and leads to increased team effectiveness. Here's nice quote from Thought Works Martin Fowler which sums it up quite nicely.
thought.quote: Any fool can write code that a computer can understand. Good programmers write code that humans can understand.

thought.author: Chinese Proverb
description: ðŸŽ¯ Regardless of your specific industry, area of expertise or [INSERT WHATEVER YOU WANT HERE], if you want to be successful and grow in the future, the best time to act is now.

Today's #ThoughtsOnProgramming features a Chinese proverb which we've shamelessly stolen from Will Sack's presentation "How to fundraise successfully during a pandemic". Will is the founder of Kindara, a digital health platform and community for women. He also provides training for entrepreneurs on fundraising through his accelerator program at GetFunded.
thought.quote: The best time to plant a tree was 20 years ago. The second best time is now.
